document_title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells
summary_full: This study investigated the impact of simulated microgravity (sμG) on the cytotoxic activity of human Natural Killer (NK) cells against leukemic cells, relevant to cancer risk in astronauts exposed to space radiation. NK cells were cultured for 48 hours under normal gravity and sμG. Cytotoxicity assays were performed using standard methods and under continuous sμG. Results showed that sμG significantly reduced NK cell cytotoxicity against both chronic myeloid leukemia (K-562) and T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (MOLT-4) cells. These inhibitory effects were more pronounced when the cytotoxicity assay was conducted under continuous sμG. RNA sequencing revealed alterations in gene expression pathways in NK cells exposed to sμG, including the induction of genes associated with impaired cytotoxicity (e.g., CD1 isoforms, CD5, CD55, CD47) and downregulation of activating receptors. The findings suggest that microgravity may increase astronaut risk of leukemogenesis, particularly for T-ALL, due to combined effects with space radiation. The study highlights the need for countermeasures to mitigate these immune deficits during long-duration space missions.
key_findings: Simulated microgravity (sμG) significantly reduces human NK cell cytotoxic activity against K-562 (CML) and MOLT-4 (T-ALL) leukemic cells.
The impairment of NK cell cytotoxicity is more pronounced when assays are conducted under continuous sμG compared to standard protocols.
RNA-seq analysis revealed significant changes in NK cell gene expression under sμG, including upregulation of inhibitory molecules and downregulation of activating receptors.
Specific genes upregulated by sμG include CD1 isoforms, CD5, CD55, CD47, and LAIR1, which are known to inhibit NK cell function.
The reduced NK cell cytotoxicity against T-ALL cells in microgravity conditions, combined with prior findings of radiation-induced T-ALL, suggests an increased risk for astronauts.
Microgravity exposure may lead to NK cells reverting to a more immature, stem-like state, potentially affecting their anti-tumor surveillance capabilities.
future_research_fields: Development of countermeasures to mitigate microgravity-induced NK cell dysfunction.
Investigating the specific molecular pathways altered by microgravity to identify therapeutic targets.
Assessing the combined effects of space radiation and microgravity on NK cell function and leukemogenesis in more complex models.
Exploring the potential for NK cell regression to an immature state and its implications for immune reconstitution in space.
Evaluating the efficacy of different target cell lines in masking or revealing microgravity effects on NK cells.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity significantly impairs human NK cell cytotoxic activity against leukemic cells, with effects being more pronounced under continuous microgravity conditions. These findings, particularly the reduced cytotoxicity against T-ALL cells, raise concerns about increased astronaut risk of leukemogenesis during prolonged space missions due to the combined effects of microgravity and space radiation. RNA-seq data provide mechanistic insights into these deficits, suggesting potential targets for countermeasures.
impact_statement: This study reveals that microgravity impairs the immune system's ability to fight cancer, potentially increasing cancer risk for astronauts on long space missions.
